Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Broadening Participation for STEM Women of Color

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program has identified evidence-based leadership and professional development of faculty as one of its priorities and is committed to funding innovative models and approaches that will: broaden the full participation of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM, improve STEM education and educator development at any level, and increase the development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce. With support from the National Science Foundation, Fielding Graduate University, in partnership with the Society of STEM Women of Color, Inc., proposes to enhance and implement the STEM Women of Color Conclave as a Broadening Participation Workshop series that will facilitate the preparation of a cadre of its participants for academic leadership roles. GPRA Strategic Management, Inc. (GPRASMi) will serve as the collaborative organizational partner in implementing the proposed Conclave Workshops. This effort will foster a strategic collaboration and provide access to formal postgraduate training in leadership studies. The overall goal of this effort is to increase the representation of STEM women of color in academic leadership positions by enhancing the quality of the leadership development experience. The proposed Conclave Workshops will heighten the profile of STEM women faculty of color who, in turn, will constitute a powerful knowledge network for broadening participation through effective academic leadership. As a long-term outcome, the proposed leadership development experience for women of color is likely to yield a cadre of academic leaders with the acumen needed to address the shifting demands of higher education, and the cultural sensitivity to yield academic success and better STEM career outcomes, particularly among underrepresented minorities. As such, the proposed Workshops will extend beyond the leadership capacity of its participants to the thousands of underrepresented minority students with whom they will interact.

The proposed project will enhance the leadership development experience for women of color who provide the kind of academic and psychosocial support for underrepresented minority students that leads to better STEM learning outcomes by: 1) convening broadening participation workshops focused on leadership development for STEM women of color; and 2) providing access to opportunities to earn continuing education credits as credentials necessary for acquiring legitimacy in and contributing to STEM academic leadership. The specific objectives are: 1) to convene a two-day Broadening Participation Workshop: National Conclave for STEM Women of Color; and 2) to provide access to continuing education (CE) credits for Conclave participants. This project will contribute to redefining higher education leadership to meaningfully include an awareness of, affinity for, and sensitivity to the academic and psychosocial needs of underrepresented minority students, thereby broadening participation. Collectively, these efforts are expected to impact a network of thousands of STEM higher education reformers committed to diversifying STEM faculty, as well as a wider pool of faculty and academic administrators, from all disciplines, who are committed to recruiting and retaining STEM women faculty of color.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While research literature has identified teaching quality as one of the most consistent predictors of minority student interest and retention in the STEM fields, research and programs to develop more robust approaches for broadening the participation of underrepresented minorities in STEM must expand beyond the student (Tsui, 2007). Recent evidence has revealed persistent disparities in academic leadership that disproportionately marginalize women of color. This phenomenon is particularly alarming given that the number of women and minorities in the current educational landscape is increasing dramatically. Furthermore, recent studies have identified the presence of women of color faculty major contributors to better retention and career outcomes for undergraduate women of color in STEM (Bettinger & Long, 2005; Trower & Chait, 2002). These data suggest that efforts should specifically examine effective academic leadership since this area not only comprehensively impacts student outcomes, but also institutional efficacy and transformation.

Generous funding from the National Science Foundation allowed for the creation of a strategic collaborative partnership between Fielding Graduate University and the Society of STEM Women of Color, Inc. (NSF Award #1613330) designed to deliver broadening participation workshops focused on leadership development for STEM women of color who serve as faculty members and emerging leaders in colleges and universities throughout the United States.

The overarching goal of the Conclave Leadership Academy (CLA) was to increase the representation of STEM women of color in academic leadership positions by providing an enhanced leadership development experience. This was accomplished through Fielding Graduate University's development of specialized leadership training for a cadre of participants in the STEM Women of Color ConclaveTM - now the largest national gathering of STEM women faculty of color. The CLA was strategically designed to provide women in the STEM disciplines with additional critical knowledge and skills in order to more actively engage in academic leadership roles of various types within their STEM disciplines, institutional administration, and at the national level. This unique effort represents a radical departure from the traditional leadership development efforts, which are often generalized across disciplines and devoid of any differentiated focus on race/gender intersectionality. By focusing on women of color, Fielding Graduate University and the Society of STEM Women of Color, Inc. contribute to redefining higher education leadership to meaningfully include an acute and authentic awareness of, affinity for, and sensitivity to the academic and psychosocial needs of underrepresented minority students - thereby moving the proverbial needle on broadening participation.

In just two years, this collaborative program has trained a total of 134 STEM women of color faculty and emerging leaders from colleges and universities throughout the United States (including PWIs, HBCUs, HSIs and TCUs). These scholars earned an academic leadership certificate, with up to ten continuing education units (CEUs), from Fielding Graduate University upon their successful completion of the programmatic activities. The CLA further strengthened a network of leaders within these academic disciplines who comprise a distinctive community. They possess the cultural knowledge necessary to fully define and examine unique leadership issues that can increase the participation of women of color in the STEM fields and develop more nationally diverse institutions. These women are also able to develop cross-cultural relationships to support each other through their career trajectories.

As a long-term outcome, the proposed leadership development experience for women of color is likely to yield a cadre of academic leaders with the acumen needed to address the shifting demands of higher education, and the cultural sensitivity to yield academic success and better STEM career outcomes, particularly among underrepresented minorities (Bettinger & Long, 2005). As such, the broader impact of the program will extend beyond the leadership capacity of its participants to the thousands of underrepresented minority students with whom they will interact.

For specific questions or comments about this program and/or the information included in this NSF Project Outcomes Report, please contact the Director of STEM Continuing Education and Special Projects by email at mewynn@fielding.edu.
